title: PTD Today — Media

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this Google film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and links themes of AI, data, and creativity with the unseen world of data centers. No transcript is available, but the title indicates a focus on how AI empowers artists within the broader data-center ecosystem.
bullets: Produced by Google as a companion film to Season 5 of Where the Internet Lives.
Core themes indicated: AI, data, creativity, and the unseen infrastructure of data centers.
No transcript is available for this video.
Published 2026-01-15; positions creative AI alongside data-center infrastructure issues.
Uses hashtags: #WhereTheInternetLives #AI #Data #Creativity
takeaways: If the film ties AI-driven creative workloads to data centers, expect signals that demand for compute and associated power capacity may grow—plan capacity and cooling accordingly.
Narratives linking creativity and infrastructure can be used to justify investments in energy efficiency, renewables integration, and flexible load management to accommodate variable AI workloads.

Communicating these stories externally is an opportunity for operators to highlight sustainability measures and procurement strategies (including hardware lifecycle and critical-minerals considerations) to stakeholders.
Edge and distributed capacity considerations may be relevant if creative AI workflows emphasize latency or localized collaboration—evaluate siting and interconnect needs.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Product Manager, Cloud Networking at Google) explains how networking must be AI-aware to support efficient inference. He outlines Google Cloud’s approach—using the GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing with inference-specific metrics, prefix caching, body-based routing and service extensions—to reduce latency, improve GPU utilization, and insert guardrails at the network edge.
bullets: Traditional networking and metrics (CPU-based, round-robin LB) can hide GPU/TPU congestion and misroute inference traffic.
GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing use metrics like KV cache utilization and queue depth to identify least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations to reduce GPU work and cold starts.
Body-based routing and LoRA-adapter awareness enable routing by model/context and unified APIs for multiple models.
Service Extensions let operators insert API management and AI guardrails (prompt/response sanitization) at the network layer to block invalid requests before they consume GPU cycles.
takeaways: Maximize GPU utilization — AI-aware networking reduces wasted GPU cycles, lowering compute demand and data-center power draw.
Reduce peak/latency risk — smarter routing and cache reuse smooths workload spikes, which can ease power provisioning and cooling stress.
Lower operational TCO — cutting cold starts and invalid model calls reduces GPU runtime and energy costs for inference-heavy services.
Simplify governance — network-inserted guardrails centralize policy enforcement and can prevent costly or noncompliant compute before it runs.
Monitoring needs to change — operations teams should adopt inference-specific metrics (e.g., KV cache use, queue depth) rather than relying solely on CPU.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short trailer spotlights Where Winds Meet, an open-world martial arts RPG running with NVIDIA graphics features. It emphasizes DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and #RTXOn; video credit is given to DigitalDreamsyt.
bullets: Where Winds Meet — open-world martial arts RPG.
Highlights DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation.
Promoted with #RTXOn (NVIDIA RTX features enabled).
Focus is on visual/engine tech rather than gameplay details.
Video credit: DigitalDreamsyt.
takeaways: Mention of DLSS 4 / Multi Frame Generation implies AI-driven upscaling/inference workloads — expect higher GPU utilization when running or hosting such tech.
‘RTX On’ signals real-time ray-tracing workloads that can increase GPU power draw and cooling needs in servers or render farms.
Capacity planning for power, cooling, and rack density should account for accelerated GPU use if supporting RTX/DLSS-enabled services or game-streaming.
Edge or cloud gaming deployments may see improved client performance but higher server-side GPU cycles; factor this into resource allocation and cost models.
Scaling hardware procurement to support these features involves assessing GPU supply chains and exposure to critical-minerals sourcing risks.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova's video stresses the importance of anticipating an aging steam turbine rotor’s remaining life and outlines what to do next to maintain plant reliability. It frames rotor end-of-life assessment as a practical step for sustaining steam plant performance while supporting broader electrification and decarbonization goals.
bullets: Highlights critical need to assess remaining life of steam turbine rotors.
Frames the rotor as the backbone of steam plant reliability.
Promises guidance on next steps (assessment, intervention, or replacement).
Directs viewers to a GE Vernova resource for more detail: vernova.is/rotor-EOL.
Positions GE Vernova as a provider supporting electrification and decarbonization.
takeaways: Proactive rotor end-of-life assessment reduces risk of unplanned outages that can affect grid stability and data center backup availability.
Early evaluation enables better capital planning, spare parts procurement, and scheduled maintenance to minimize operational disruption.
Condition monitoring or life-extension options can defer costly replacements and help maintain reliability while meeting decarbonization objectives.
Engage vendor resources (e.g., GE Vernova) for technical evaluation and recommended next steps to align maintenance with system resiliency needs.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description (no transcript provided), KPMG Poland’s podcast discusses how the luxury goods market is transforming—emphasizing experiential luxury, ESG/responsible luxury, and the rise of "affordable luxury"—and why Poland’s market is still growing despite global softness. Experts Andrzej Marczak and Tomasz Wiśniewski cover trends from luxury fatigue and concentration of wealth to Gen Z preferences, luxury tourism, the art market, and the role of AI, craftsmanship and human experience in the sector’s future.
bullets: Global trends: "luxury fatigue," concentration of spending (top ~2% account for ~40% of market), and a shift toward experiences over ownership.
Personalization and exclusive customer experiences are key, with Gen Z prioritizing experiences and new aspirational consumer segments emerging.
ESG and responsible luxury matter increasingly—topics include eco-leathers, certifications and lower‑impact supply chains.
Poland: market is growing but fragmented; luxury tourism, hotels and art scenes are notable domestic drivers.
Future drivers highlighted: AI-enabled services, continued emphasis on craftsmanship, and maintaining a human dimension in luxury offerings.
takeaways: Growing luxury tourism and premium hospitality in Poland can create localized electricity demand peaks—consider targeted grid reinforcement and contingency planning for coastal and resort areas.

AI, personalization and back‑end digital services for luxury brands increase compute needs—data-center capacity planning should anticipate higher power, cooling and reliability requirements tied to e‑commerce and real‑time personalization.

ESG-driven purchasing implies brands will prefer low‑carbon power and verifiable certifications—opportunities for renewables, green power contracts, and on‑site storage to serve premium customers and meet brand commitments.

Rising demand for climate‑controlled spaces (galleries, high-end retail, storage for art/wines) points to greater HVAC and backup power needs—design for resilient, efficient power and cooling systems and consider battery or critical-commodity availability in procurement.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection has prioritized reliability since 1927. The video explains how PJM works to make sure electricity is there when you need it.
bullets: Emphasizes PJM’s long-standing, primary focus on reliability (since 1927).
Describes how PJM works to ensure electricity availability when needed.
Intended to inform viewers about PJM’s operational role in keeping the lights on.
No transcript was available for this video; summary derives from the provided description.
takeaways: If you manage data centers or other critical loads in PJM territory, prioritize understanding PJM’s reliability processes and coordination expectations.
Grid operators and planners should view PJM’s reliability focus as a baseline when assessing interconnection, outage planning, and contingency readiness.
Project developers for renewables and storage should consider how PJM’s operational priorities affect integration timelines and operational requirements.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames grid modernization as a need to balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. Their emphasis is on digital-first power grid technologies that improve stability, reduce downtime, and optimize performance across the system.
bullets: Power systems must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency as capacity expands for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy positions digital technologies as central to modern grid solutions.
Digitalization aims to improve grid stability and reduce operational downtime.
Optimization is targeted at every level of the power system to boost performance.
takeaways: Prioritize digital grid investments that can increase uptime and stabilize operations for substations and critical power assets.
Plan capacity upgrades with flexibility in mind to better integrate renewables and energy storage.
Use system-level digital optimization to lower downtime and improve efficiency for data center power and grid infrastructure.
Evaluate vendors on their digital capabilities and track record in delivering stability and performance improvements.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, resilient industries depend on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy says it works with customers and partners to build smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience hinges on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy collaborates with customers and partners to implement smarter systems.
Primary goals cited: improved productivity, increased reliability, and greater sustainability.
Focus is on operational improvements across industrial activities.
A link to learn more is provided in the description.
takeaways: Grid/substation teams should prioritize digital integration and process optimization to enhance reliability and operational efficiency.
Data center power managers can focus on energy-efficiency measures and system-level optimization to improve uptime and sustainability.
Renewables and storage planners benefit from integrating digital tools to increase productivity and better support grid operations.
Partnering with technology providers can accelerate implementation of productivity, reliability, and sustainability improvements.
